headline: DeWine signs bill to extend military ballot deadline for upcoming primary
author: Haley BeMiller
sentences: "The mission right now is to pass constitutional, fair maps, and to give every Ohioan – and of course our service men and women – the ability to speak through their vote," said state Rep. Casey Weinstein, D-Hudson, a U.S. Air Force veteran.

The move comes after tensions over the May primary escalated earlier this week when House Democrats sought to pressure Republicans to postpone the May primary election by refusing to extend military ballot deadlines.

The ballots would have to be ready by April 4 instead of March 19
The Ohio Supreme Court will soon decide whether a third set of House and Senate maps and second congressional map pass constitutional muster.

Haley BeMiller is a reporter for the USA TODAY Network Ohio Bureau, which serves the Columbus Dispatch, Cincinnati Enquirer, Akron Beacon Journal and 18 other affiliated news organizations across Ohio.

More money to expedite military ballots
House Democrats initially blocked the overseas ballot measure, but Republicans used a procedural maneuver to pass it without their support late Wednesday.
Lawmakers and election officials have been contending with overseas ballots since the U.S. Department of Defense denied Ohio's request to delay sending them to voters.

The bill signed by DeWine will narrow the window to 30 days, expedite the mailing process and give out-of-country voters 10 extra days to return their ballots.
With those hanging in the balance, Democrats argued lawmakers should postpone the primary and said the dilemma over military ballots could have been avoided.
